up.name: Up Quark
up.info: Lightest quark, found in protons and neutrons. Two up quarks + one down quark = proton

down.name: Down Quark
down.info: Second lightest quark, essential for nuclear stability. Two down quarks + one up quark = neutron

charm.name: Charm Quark
charm.info: Second generation quark, found in J/ψ meson. Discovery confirmed quark model

strange.name: Strange Quark
strange.info: Creates 'strange' particles in cosmic rays. Named for unexpected behavior in kaons

top.name: Top Quark
top.info: Heaviest elementary particle, as heavy as a gold atom! Decays before hadronization

bottom.name: Bottom Quark
bottom.info: Also called 'beauty', important for CP violation studies and B-meson physics

electron.name: Electron
electron.info: First elementary particle discovered by J.J. Thomson, makes chemistry possible

muon.name: Muon
muon.info: Heavy electron, penetrates matter deeply. Created in cosmic ray showers

tau.name: Tau
tau.info: Heaviest lepton, decays in 10⁻¹³ seconds. Only lepton heavy enough to decay into hadrons

e_neutrino.name: Electron Neutrino
e_neutrino.info: Ghostly particle that barely interacts. Billions pass through you every second from the Sun

mu_neutrino.name: Muon Neutrino
mu_neutrino.info: Second neutrino flavor discovered at Brookhaven. Oscillates with other neutrino types

tau_neutrino.name: Tau Neutrino
tau_neutrino.info: Last Standard Model particle to be directly observed at Fermilab

photon.name: Photon
photon.info: Quantum of light, mediates electromagnetic force. Massless, travels at speed c

w_boson.name: W Boson
w_boson.info: Mediates weak force, causes beta decay. Nobel Prize to Rubbia and van der Meer

z_boson.name: Z Boson
z_boson.info: Neutral weak force carrier. Discovery at CERN confirmed electroweak theory

gluon.name: Gluon
gluon.info: Carries strong force, self-interacting! 8 types corresponding to color combinations

higgs.name: Higgs Boson
higgs.info: Gives mass to other particles through Higgs mechanism. Nobel Prize 2013 to Higgs and Englert

sections.title: Elementary Particle Physics
sections.subtitle: A Journey from the Universe to Its Smallest Building Blocks
sections.demo_text:
Welcome to an interactive exploration of the fundamental nature of reality.
Scroll down to begin your journey through scales, particles, and forces.

cards.title: From Cosmos to Quarks: A Journey of Scale
content: The universe spans an incredible range of scales. From the observable universe at 10²⁶ meters to the smallest meaningful length (Planck length) at 10⁻³⁵ meters, we traverse 61 orders of magnitude!
Each scale reveals different physics - from general relativity at cosmic scales to quantum mechanics at atomic scales.

content.text: Each step down in scale reveals new physics:

items: 10²⁶ m (Observable Universe): Dark energy dominates, spacetime expands
10²¹ m (Galaxy): Dark matter halos, gravitational dynamics
10¹² m (Solar System): Orbital mechanics, tidal forces
10⁶ m (Earth): Geophysics, atmospheric phenomena
10⁰ m (Human scale): Classical mechanics dominates
10⁻³ m (Millimeter): Surface tension becomes important
10⁻⁶ m (Micrometer): Brownian motion visible
10⁻⁹ m (Nanoscale): Quantum effects become noticeable
10⁻¹⁰ m (Atomic): Electron orbitals, chemistry happens here
10⁻¹⁵ m (Nuclear): Strong force dominates, quarks confined
10⁻¹⁸ m (Deep inelastic): Quarks behave as free particles
10⁻³⁵ m (Planck length): Quantum gravity regime, spacetime foam

content.text: The de Broglie wavelength sets the quantum scale:
When λ ≈ size of system, quantum mechanics is essential!
The Compton wavelength λc = h/(mc) gives the scale where particle creation becomes important

cards.title: Memory Trick: Powers of Ten
content: "Mega Kittens Have Dancing Cats, Miniature μnicorns Nap Peacefully Femtosecond Attosecond"
Mega (10⁶), Kilo (10³), Hecto (10²), Deca (10¹), Centi (10⁻²), Milli (10⁻³), Micro (10⁻⁶), Nano (10⁻⁹), Pico (10⁻¹²), Femto (10⁻¹⁵), Atto (10⁻¹⁸)

cards.title: The Atomic Theory Evolution
content: For centuries, we believed atoms were indivisible - the word literally means 'uncuttable' in Greek. But the discovery of radioactivity in 1896 changed everything!
Today we know that atoms consist of a nucleus (protons and neutrons made of quarks) surrounded by electron clouds in quantum orbitals.
Remarkably, 99.9999999999996% of an atom is empty space! If a nucleus were the size of a marble, the electron cloud would extend to a football stadium.

items: 400 BCE: Democritus proposes atomos concept
1803: Dalton's atomic theory
1897: J.J. Thomson discovers the electron (plum pudding model)
1909: Millikan measures electron charge
1911: Rutherford's gold foil experiment reveals the nucleus
1913: Bohr model of hydrogen atom
1926: Schrödinger equation describes electron orbitals
1932: Chadwick discovers the neutron
1964: Gell-Mann and Zweig propose quarks
1968: Deep inelastic scattering confirms quarks
1974: J/ψ particle confirms charm quark
1995: Top quark discovered at Fermilab
2012: Higgs boson discovered at CERN

content.title: CERN Connection
content.text: The Large Hadron Collider recreates conditions from 10⁻¹² seconds after the Big Bang, when the temperature was 10¹⁶ Kelvin and quarks roamed free in a quark-gluon plasma before being confined into protons and neutrons!
Where n, l, m are quantum numbers defining energy, angular momentum, and magnetic orientation

cards.title: The Standard Model: Nature's LEGO Set
content: All matter and forces (except gravity) arise from just 17 fundamental particles. Think of them as nature's LEGO blocks - simple pieces that build our complex universe!
These particles are divided into two main categories: Fermions (matter particles with half-integer spin) and Bosons (force carriers with integer spin).

content.text: Every particle has an antimatter twin with opposite charge but same mass. When matter meets antimatter: E = mc² in action - pure energy release!
CPT theorem states that physics is invariant under combined Charge conjugation, Parity inversion, and Time reversal - the deepest symmetry in physics.

cards.title: Memory Tricks for Particles
content: Quarks: "University Dorms Can Seem Terribly Boring" (Up, Down, Charm, Strange, Top, Bottom)
Leptons: "Every Monday Teachers Explain Math Topics" (Electron, Muon, Tau + their Neutrinos)
Bosons: "Photons Glow, Weak Zaps Happen" (Photon, Gluon, W, Z, Higgs)

cards.title: Quarks: The Nuclear LEGO Blocks
content: Quarks never exist alone - they're always confined in groups due to the nature of the strong force. This confinement creates two types of particles:
• Baryons: Three quarks (like protons and neutrons)
• Mesons: Quark-antiquark pairs (like pions and kaons)
Two up quarks + one down quark = proton (uud, charge +1)
Two down quarks + one up quark = neutron (udd, charge 0)

content.text: Quarks carry 'color charge' (red, green, blue) - nothing to do with actual colors! It's a quantum number like electric charge.

items: Baryons: 3 quarks with RGB colors combine to be 'colorless' (white)
Mesons: quark + antiquark with color + anticolor = colorless
Gluons: Carry color-anticolor combinations, 8 types total

content.text: The strong force potential between quarks:
First term: Coulomb-like attraction at short distances
Second term: Linear confinement at large distances
As quarks separate, energy increases linearly until it's energetically favorable to create new quark-antiquark pairs from the vacuum!

content.title: ALICE Detector: Quark-Gluon Plasma
content.text: The ALICE detector at CERN studies quark-gluon plasma - a state where quarks are deconfined at temperatures above 2 trillion Kelvin, recreating conditions microseconds after the Big Bang. In this state, quarks and gluons move freely in a 'perfect liquid' with near-zero viscosity!

cards.title: Leptons: The Independent Particles
content: Unlike quarks, leptons can exist alone. The electron is the most familiar - it makes chemistry possible by forming bonds between atoms.
Each charged lepton has a neutral partner (neutrino) that barely interacts with matter.
Lepton flavor is conserved in most processes, but neutrinos violate this through oscillations!

content.text: Neutrinos change flavor as they travel! A muon neutrino can become an electron neutrino mid-flight. This proves neutrinos have mass (Nobel Prize 2015 to Kajita and McDonald).
The Sun produces only electron neutrinos, but we detect all three types on Earth - solving the 'solar neutrino problem'.
Where θ is mixing angle, Δm² is mass difference squared, L is distance, E is energy
Why are neutrinos so light? The seesaw mechanism suggests extremely heavy 'sterile' neutrinos (10¹⁵ GeV) balance the scales, making observed neutrinos ultra-light (< 1 eV).

cards.title: Forces = Particle Exchange
content: Imagine two ice skaters throwing a heavy ball back and forth - they push apart. That's how forces work at the quantum level!
Particles exchange force carriers (bosons) to create attractive or repulsive forces.
The range of a force depends on the mass of its carrier: massless carriers (photon, gluon) give infinite range, massive carriers (W, Z) give short range.

content.text: Force carriers can be 'virtual' - they exist for such short times that they can violate energy conservation temporarily.
A virtual particle with energy ΔE can exist for time Δt ≈ ℏ/(2ΔE)
Each force corresponds to a gauge symmetry - a mathematical transformation that leaves physics unchanged:

items: Electromagnetic: U(1) symmetry → 1 Photon
Weak: SU(2) symmetry → 3 bosons (W⁺, W⁻, Z⁰)
Strong: SU(3) symmetry → 8 Gluons
Electroweak unification: SU(2)×U(1) → Unified at high energy

content.text: Where Fμν = ∂μAν - ∂νAμ + ig[Aμ,Aν] is the field strength tensor

cards.title: Why Do Particles Have Mass?
content: Imagine a celebrity walking through a crowded room - fans cluster around, slowing them down. The Higgs field fills all of space, and particles that interact with it gain mass!
The Higgs field has a non-zero value everywhere in space (vacuum expectation value), unlike other fields.
Different particles couple to the Higgs field with different strengths, giving them different masses.

content.text: The Higgs field has a unique potential shaped like a Mexican hat (wine bottle bottom). The field 'rolls' to a minimum value, breaking the symmetry of the laws of physics.
This vacuum expectation value (vev) sets the electroweak scale!
Particle masses: m = gv/√2, where g is the Yukawa coupling
Breaking a continuous symmetry creates massless Goldstone bosons. In the Higgs mechanism, these are 'eaten' by the W and Z bosons, giving them mass and a longitudinal polarization.

cards.title: The 2012 Discovery at CERN
content: On July 4, 2012, CERN announced the discovery of the Higgs boson - the quantum excitation of the Higgs field.
It took: 10,000 scientists, 50 years of theory, 30 years of construction, and collisions at 99.999999% the speed of light!
Detection signatures:
• H → γγ (two photons) - Clean but rare
• H → ZZ → 4 leptons - 'Golden channel'
• H → WW → leptons + neutrinos
• H → bb̄ (bottom quarks) - Most common but hard to detect
The discovery confirmed the last missing piece of the Standard Model and earned François Englert and Peter Higgs the 2013 Nobel Prize.

cards.title: Spin: Not Really Spinning!
content: Quantum spin is like an internal compass needle that can only point in specific directions. It's intrinsic angular momentum - particles have it even when standing still!
Spin determines particle statistics: Fermions (half-integer spin) obey Pauli exclusion, Bosons (integer spin) can occupy the same state.
Spin is quantized: measured in units of ℏ/2 (spin-1/2, spin-1, etc.)

content.text:
*Possibly violated by proton decay (not observed)
**Violated by neutrino oscillations
***Violated in weak interactions and B meson decays
The deepest symmetry: physics is unchanged under combined Charge conjugation, Parity inversion, and Time reversal. Any Lorentz-invariant quantum field theory must be CPT symmetric.
Where s is spin quantum number, m is magnetic quantum number (-s ≤ m ≤ s)

cards.title: Quantum Number Rules
content: Spin Statistics: "Fermions are Antisocial" (Pauli exclusion)
Bosons are Social: "Photons Party Together" (can pile up)
Conservation: "BLESS" - Baryon, Lepton, Energy, Strangeness, Spin (angular momentum)

cards.title: Feynman Diagrams: The Comic Strips of Physics
content: Richard Feynman invented these diagrams to visualize and calculate particle interactions. Time flows left to right, and each vertex represents an interaction point.
Every line and vertex has a mathematical meaning - these aren't just pictures, they're calculation tools!
Each diagram represents a quantum amplitude that must be squared and summed over all possibilities.

content.text: Each diagram element contributes a factor to the amplitude:

items: Vertex: Coupling constant (e for EM, g for strong)
Internal line (propagator): 1/(q² - m²) for virtual particles
External line: Wave function for real particles
Loop: Integration over internal momentum

content.text: Total amplitude = Sum of all possible diagrams:
Each order adds more vertices. For QED, α ≈ 1/137 makes series converge.
For QCD at low energy, αₛ ≈ 1, so perturbation theory fails (confinement regime).

cards.title: Decay Processes
content: Particles decay through the weak force when energetically allowed. The lifetime depends on the coupling strength and available phase space.
Common decay modes:
• Beta decay: n → p + e⁻ + ν̄ₑ (neutron decay)
• Muon decay: μ⁻ → e⁻ + ν̄ₑ + νμ
• Pion decay: π⁺ → μ⁺ + νμ

cards.title: How to 'See' Subatomic Particles
content: Particles leave tracks like planes leave contrails. Different particles create unique signatures in detectors based on how they interact with matter.
Modern detectors are like 3D cameras the size of buildings, taking 40 million pictures per second!
Each particle type has a characteristic signature based on which detector layers it penetrates.

items: 1. Vertex Detector: Silicon pixels, 10μm resolution, finds decay vertices
2. Tracker: Silicon strips, measures momentum from track curvature in magnetic field
3. ECAL (Electromagnetic Calorimeter): Lead tungstate crystals, stops photons/electrons
4. HCAL (Hadronic Calorimeter): Brass/scintillator sandwich, stops hadrons
5. Magnet: Superconducting solenoid, 4 Tesla field for momentum measurement
6. Muon Chambers: Gas detectors, only muons penetrate this far

content.text: • dE/dx: Energy loss rate identifies particle type
• Cherenkov radiation: Measures velocity for particle ID
• Transition radiation: Distinguishes electrons from pions

cards.title: The LHC: Humanity's Most Complex Machine
content: Scale & Performance:
• Circumference: 27 km underground ring
• Temperature: 1.9 K (-271.3°C) - colder than outer space!
• Vacuum: 10⁻¹³ atm - emptier than interplanetary space
• Collision rate: 600 million collisions/second
• Energy: 13.6 TeV (Run 3) - like mosquitoes with the energy of a fastball
• Data rate: 30 petabytes/year (30 million GB)
The Four Main Detectors:
• ATLAS: A Toroidal LHC ApparatuS - 46m long, 7000 tons
• CMS: Compact Muon Solenoid - 'compact' but weighs 14,000 tons
• ALICE: Studies quark-gluon plasma from lead-ion collisions
• LHCb: Specializes in b-quark physics and matter-antimatter asymmetry
Superconducting Magnets:
• 1,232 dipole magnets at 8.33 Tesla (200,000× Earth's field)
• Use 96 tons of superfluid helium
• Store energy equivalent to 400 tons of TNT when operational

cards.title: The Equations That Rule the Universe
content: These equations encode all known particle physics (except gravity). Each symbol tells a story about the fundamental nature of reality.
From Schrödinger's equation for atoms to the Standard Model Lagrangian, mathematics is the language of the quantum world.

equations.name: 1. Schrödinger Equation (Non-relativistic QM)
equations.description: Describes how quantum states evolve in time

equations.name: 2. Dirac Equation (Relativistic electrons)
equations.description: Predicted antimatter! Combines QM with special relativity

equations.name: 3. Klein-Gordon Equation (Scalar particles)
equations.description: Describes spin-0 particles like the Higgs

equations.name: 4. Yang-Mills Equation (Force fields)
equations.description: Describes how force fields propagate and interact

ψ̄γ^μD_μψ: Fermion kinetic energy and gauge interactions
Y_{ij}ψ_jφ: Yukawa couplings (fermion masses)
|D_μφ|²: Higgs kinetic energy
V(φ): Higgs potential (symmetry breaking)

Where S[φ] = ∫d⁴x ℒ(φ) is the action
This integral includes all possible field configurations connecting initial and final states
QED: α increases with energy (asymptotic slavery)
QCD: α_s decreases with energy (asymptotic freedom - Nobel 2004)

cards.title: The Universe's Unsolved Mysteries
content: The Standard Model explains only 5% of the universe! Dark matter (27%) and dark energy (68%) remain complete mysteries.
Other puzzles: Why is there more matter than antimatter? Why is gravity so weak? Are there extra dimensions?
The next breakthrough in physics will likely come from solving one of these mysteries.

items: Dark Matter: Invisible mass holding galaxies together. Candidates: WIMPs, axions, sterile neutrinos
Dark Energy: Mysterious force accelerating cosmic expansion. Related to cosmological constant?
Matter-Antimatter Asymmetry: Why did matter win? CP violation insufficient to explain
Hierarchy Problem: Why is gravity 10³² times weaker than the weak force?
Neutrino Masses: Why so tiny? Seesaw mechanism? Majorana nature?
Strong CP Problem: Why doesn't the strong force violate CP? Axions?
Quantum Gravity: How to unify QM with general relativity?
Every particle has a 'superpartner' with spin differing by 1/2
Solves hierarchy problem, provides dark matter candidate
Predicts: selectron, squark, gluino, neutralino, etc.

Spacetime itself is quantized at Planck scale

cards.title: The Future of Particle Physics
content: Current & Near-Future Experiments:
• LHC High-Luminosity Upgrade (2029): 10× more data for precision studies
• DUNE (2028): Neutrino beam from Fermilab to South Dakota
• Belle II: Precision B-physics in Japan
• Muon g-2: Testing Standard Model predictions at Fermilab
Proposed Future Colliders:
• FCC (Future Circular Collider): 100 km ring at CERN, 100 TeV collisions
• ILC (International Linear Collider): Precision Higgs factory
• CLIC: Compact linear collider, up to 3 TeV
• Muon Collider: Clean collisions, less synchrotron radiation
Dark Matter Searches:
• Direct Detection: XENON, LUX-ZEPLIN, PandaX - underground detectors
• Indirect Detection: AMS-02 on ISS, Fermi telescope
• Collider Production: Looking for missing energy at LHC
Quantum Computing for Physics:
Future quantum computers could simulate quantum field theories directly, solving problems impossible for classical computers!

cards.title: Remember the Mysteries: 'DANG HMS'
content: Dark matter - What is 27% of the universe?
Asymmetry - Why more matter than antimatter?
Neutrino masses - Why so tiny?
Gravity - Why so weak? How to quantize?
Hierarchy problem - Natural mass scales?
Multiverse? - Are we one of many?
Supersymmetry? - Beautiful but hidden?

cards.title: 🎯 Quick Reference Card
content: You've traveled from the vastness of the universe to its smallest constituents!
The Standard Model at a Glance:
✅ 6 Quarks: up, down, charm, strange, top, bottom
✅ 6 Leptons: electron, muon, tau + their neutrinos
✅ 5 Force Carriers: photon, W±, Z, 8 gluons, Higgs
✅ 4 Fundamental Forces: strong, electromagnetic, weak, (gravity*)
Key Principles:
• Everything is made of quantum fields
• Forces arise from symmetries (Noether's theorem)
• Mass comes from Higgs field interaction
• Antimatter is matter moving backward in time (Feynman)
• Virtual particles mediate forces
Remember: Physics is not just equations - it's the poetry of reality!
